reasoning: The critique targets a specific sub-argument in §2.4.1: under moral realism, the true view is likely alien and thus non-motivational (or avoided). That claim contributes to (but is not the sole basis of) the essay’s skepticism about WAM-convergence; the essay also leans heavily on the anti-realist branch, plus various blockers and sociological dynamics. So centrality is moderate-low (~0.3). The proposed reversal—alienness/objectivity making moral truth a Schelling point for legitimacy/coordination—does weaken the inference from “alien” to “non-motivating,” especially in a post-AGI institutional context. But it’s not a decisive refutation: it relies on speculative assumptions about how often agents/institutions will treat moral truth as focal (vs. pursue parochial goals), and it doesn’t engage the essay’s separate worry that many agents may not want de dicto moral deference at all, or may strategically choose advisors/procedures that don’t ‘certify’ alien conclusions. Hence moderate strength (~0.4). The critique is largely plausible and internally coherent, though some claims (e.g., robust certification across reflective procedures) are contestable/underspecified, so correctness is good but not near-1. Clarity is high, dead weight is minimal, and it focuses on a single issue.
title: Alien moral truths could serve as coordination Schelling points
